titlestmt.titleproper: Finding Aid for the Donald Davie Papers MSS.0101
titlestmt.author: Beverly Lee

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2018-01-29 16:25:05 -0600.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers of author, educator, poet, and critic Donald Davie consist of his writings, published and unpublished, printed and in draft form, both manuscripts and typescripts, literary correspondence, personal and biographical data, materials pertaining to his academic career and other professional activities, works of his associates and colleagues, and writings by other twentieth century poets and authors, some of them Davie's students. The earliest materials are letters Davie wrote as a young man in the Royal Navy in 1942 and the latest are his obituaries written in 1995.
The papers consist of these series:

The series Writing includes some printed material, but the majority of this series is in manuscript or typescript. An oversized box contains a handcrafted book of poems by Davie and photographs by his wife, Doreen Davie. These materials date from 1947 until 1988. The subseries are:

list.item: Tables of Contents and Book Plans

scopecontent.p: The series Correspondence (Literary) consists of incoming and outgoing correspondence. It is arranged alphabetically by the correspondent's last name. These letters range in date from 1958 until 1989.

The series Personal and Biographical Data consists of a handwritten account of his wartime experiences in Russia, personal correspondence of that era, and his obituaries. These materials range in date from 1942 until 1995. The subseries are:

The series Academic Career consists of press clippings, materials relating to his university career in Britain, and his lecture notes, arranged by subject, in typescript and manuscript. Most of the lecture notes appear to date from his seven years at Trinity College Dublin. The items in this series range in date from 1951 until 1988. The subseries are:

The series Professional Activities consists of audiocassettes and reel-to-reel tapes recorded by Davie and materials from the journal PNR during the time Davie was editor. The materials date from 1972 until? The subseries are:

The series Associates and Colleagues consists of manuscripts and printed materials by Howard Warshaw and Peter Whigham, both colleagues of Davie at Stanford, whose works he supported and promoted. The materials in this series date from 1969 until 1983. The subseries are:

The series Writings by Others consists of critiques of Davie's work and influence, proof copies Davie received to review, poetry of Davie's students, and off-prints and books written by twentieth century poets and academics on the subject of poets and poetry. These materials range in date from 1922 until 1987. The materials dated in the 1920s are Xeroxed copies of material by Ivor Gurney (d. 1937), but they were copied for Davie in 1988. The subseries are:

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Donald Davie Papers were purchased from his estate, and literary rights remain the property of his heirs. Please consult the Head of Special Collections for permission to quote or publish any part of this collection.

Gurney, Ivor. R. K. R. Thornton, ed. Ivor Gurney: Collected Letters.

Murray, Les. The Paperback Tree. Selected Prose.
Nabakov, Vladimir. The Gift. Review printed on unidentified newspaper, plus draft and notes for the review
Paz, Octavio. Helen Lane, trans. The Other Voice. Poetry and the Fin-de-siecle.
Robinson, Peter. In The Circumstances: About Poems and Poets
Rosenberg, David and Harold Bloom, trans. The Book of J.
Trickett, Rachel. Pope and the Man of Ross. The Honest Muse: A Study in Augustin Verse.
Weissbort, Daniel, ed. The Poetry of Survival. Post-War Poets of Central and Eastern Europe.
Ziolkowski, Theodore. Virgil and the Moderns
Aesthetic Value –Judgements in Literary Criticism or What Do We Mean When We Say "This is a Good Poem?" Address to the Irish Philosophical Club.
American Poetry Through British Eyes. Addressed to the Friends of the Joint University Libraries of Vanderbilt University.
Marianne Moore. A paper for the Cambridge English Club. Undated. Also a fragment of a critique of review in "Scrutiny" Vol. IV., no. 1, June 1935. pp. 87-90 of Selected Poems of Marianne Moore.
The Poet in the Imaginary Museum. Introduction to the 2nd of two talks.
The Poet Keats. Delivered to Perse School Literary Society
Poetic License and Civil Freedoms –The Poets Role in a time of Social Ferment. Address to the Wilshire Boulevard Temple, Los Angeles, California
The Russian Novel –draft of a paper for the Shirley Society
Sacred Poetry of Jack Clemo. Endowed lecture to the University of Surrey
A Tribute to Allen Tate. Delivered at Vanderbilt University –an introduction to an address by Robert Pinsky.
Values and Heritage. Delivered at Tate Gallery, London, England. Also a photocopy of an article in The Independent announcing the conference "Art and Value" with handwritten comments by Davie.
Henry Vaughn and the 17th Century Psalmists
William Butler Yeats and the Savile Club
Foreword to a Penguin reprint of Purity of Diction in English Verse
Cover by Donald Davie for Juvenilia in Verse. No Contents
English Translations of Russian Fiction in Book Form
Essays and Articles on Russian Writers of Fiction Appearing in English Periodicals Between 1882-1945
Reading List for Lectures on 18th century Poetry
Tolstoy: Bibliography of Translations into English
Works in English Upon Russian Fiction I. General Works
Works in English Upon Russian Fiction II. Specific Authors
Tables of Contents and Book Plans
Auburn, or the Civilization of North America

odd.head: General
odd.p: The book never went beyond the planning stage.

Film. 1800 feet, 7 " reel. Red label appended-reads "1-Stevenson-7 & 1/2." No other markings.

(Offprint) Inscribed. "The Definition and Practice and Literary Studies." New Literary History Vol. II, No. 1 Autumn, 1970. Inscribed.

Wiltshire, Susan. "Introduction: The Classical Tradition in the South" and "Jefferson, Calhoun, and the Slavery Debate: The Classics and the Two Minds of the South." Southern Humanities Review (Auburn, 1977) Inscribed by Susan Wiltshire to Greg Miller, May, 1979.
Davie, Donald and Doreen Davie. Romanesque Brevagna. Original book by Donald and Doreen Davie. String-tied in red paper boards, one of two sets.
A Garland of Many Years. Poems for Doreen Davie from her loving husband.
